title: YWCA of Germantown “Administration Building”
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Founded in 1870, the YWCA of Germantown opened its Gothic Revival-style Administration Building at 5820 Germantown Ave. in 1915. Expanded in 1920, it served as a vital community hub for decades. After financial struggles, the board was ousted in 1999 and the renamed Germantown Women’s Y soon closed. Purchased by Germantown Settlement in 2006 with a PRA loan, it never reopened. Fires in 2010 and 2012 followed Settlement’s bankruptcy. As of 2025, PRA has yet to find a redeveloper despite ongoing community advocacy.
imageAltText: The entrance to the YWCA building

title: YWCA for Colored Girls and Women (Branch Y)
creator: Ameer, Isbah
date: 1918 – 1952 Branch YWCA; 1958-present Germantown Settlement Music School
description: Organizing for a “Colored Branch” of the YWCA began in 1917 as 5820 Germantown Ave remained white only. In 1918, 6128 Germantown Ave opened: an older, smaller building with tennis courts but no pool. By 1919, it had over 1,000 members. Integration began in 1946 with the YWCA’s “Interracial Charter” and 6128 closed in 1952. Since 1958 it has housed the Germantown Settlement Music School. For 34 years the Branch Y was a beacon of leadership and programming. Ora Washington, a national tennis and basketball champion, is honored with a marker outside. Learn more about the Branch Y here.

title: Collins Manufacturing Company
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: One of the Industries "In 1917, YWCA centers were organized in the North American Lace Company at 1001 Glenwood Avenue and at the A. M. Collins Manufacturing Company at 226 Columbia, with classes, recreation, etc., and in each case with a YWCA Secretary whose salary was paid by the management. In 1920 the Association at the Collins plant was given up and the girls encouraged to participate as regular members of the Germantown industrial department. The North American Lace Company Association became affiliated with the YWCA of Philadelphia." (Carner)

title: Wakefield Mills
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: The first knitting mill in the US, Taylor Building at Main & Lincoln Streets in Wakefield. Owned by the Fisher family of Wakefield, the mills stopped operating in the 1880s. The YWCA was first established to help female workers from mills to find rest and recereation in the evenings

title: Germantown Town Hall
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Designed by architect Napoleon LeBrun, the building never actually served as the town hall. Over the years the building has had many uses
address: Germantown Av &, W Haines St, Philadelphia, PA 19144

title: National Bank of Germantown
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: One of Philadelphia's 27 Obsolete Banks that issued Obsolete Bank Notes during the Obsolete Bank Note Era (1782-1866). Merged with the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank taking that name, September 11, 1953

title: Pine Cottage: First YWCA Boarding Home
creator: Ameer, Isbah
date: Original “Pine Cottage” house used by YWCA in 1870. Demolished by 1873.
description: During its early years, the YWCA of Germantown rented various spaces to provide lodging and activities for young, single women working in the mills. The first was Pine Cottage or Pine Place in 1870. It had previously been the home and school of Bronson Alcott and family. Abolitionist, suffragist and author Louisa Mae Alcott, who appears on the YWCA’s  “Women of Germantown” mural was born there in 1832, but the family moved away in two years. By 1874, Pine Cottage was demolished to build a Masonic Lodge. Decades later, it became the showroom of Germantown legacy business Cunningham Piano Company until 2016. Historically designated, it is now owned by Philly Office Retail and houses apartments, Ubuntu Fine Art and Kinesics Dance Dynamics Theatre.

title: Early YWCA Boarding House Evolves into Harkness House
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Between 1873-74, the YWCA of Germantown acquired a house on the corner of “Mill and Main Streets” (today’s Church Lane and Germantown Avenue at Market Square) It was the end of three rows built by John Fromberger circa 1795. The Y converted it to boarding rooms, a cafeteria and activity space for young, single working women. In 1917, Sarah W. McLean [1863- ?) whose image is on the “Women of Germantown” mural for her YWCA leadership and philanthropy, bought the other two houses and gifted them to the Y in honor of her deceased sister, Mary Warden Harkness. The three were made into a single structure. The Y ran Harkness House until the onset of WWII, selling it in 1941.
address: 5501 Germantown Ave, Market Square, Philadelphia, PA 19144

title: Home of Elizabeth P. Smith
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: In 1869, a meeting was called at her home by Elizabeth P. Smith. This is where the Germantown YWCA began under the name of Women's Christian Association.

title: Harkness House
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Supported welfare needs for the community 1879 onwards, had a nursing agency, employment bureau,  free baths, educational programmes, surprisingly also had a physical training dept in educational programe.

title: Bryn Mawr College
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: In 1823 women industrial workers who were members of the YWCA were sent to Summer School for Industrial Workers in Bryn Mawr

title: Church of the Brethren
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: In 1969 housed the table on which the first protest in America against slavery was signed in 1688.

title: Germantown Branch of the Free Library
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: One of the 25 branches of the Free Library built from 1904 to 1930 from a $1.5 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation.

title: Center in the Park
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Previously the site of the Free Library of Philadelphia, Germantown Branch. The building has been used as a senior citizens center by the non-profit Center in the Park since 1986.

title: Vernon Park
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Vernon Park is host to monuments commemorating the Battle of Germantown, the battle was faught nearby in 1777. The Founders’ Monument is inscribed with the first documented protest against slavery in Philadelphia. The Center in the Park is also located in Vernon Park.

title: Falls of Schuykill Branch and Cafeteria
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: An early focus of the YWCA of Germantown was “industrial work” – activating working women and advocating for improved conditions. Among the mills and factories around Germantown, one of the largest was Dobson Mills, 4041-55 Ridge Avenue, operating from the 1850’s to the 1930’s. In 1905, the Germantown Association formed Falls of Schuylkill Branch at 4052 Ridge Ave. In 1920, Schuylkill had 400 members. With funds from Sarah W. McLean, they also purchased 4100-4188 Ridge Avenue as a cafeteria for the workers. “Prices were very low – roast lamb and bake potato 8 cents, soup 4 cents...” McLean, whose image is on the “Women of Germantown mural, was Branch Board Chair, 1910-1921. The branch closed in 1928 and was incorporated into the Germantown Association.(Carner)
address: Branch, 4052 Ridge Avenue; Cafeteria, 4100-4188 Ridge Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19129

title: Camp Tinicum
creator: Ameer, Isbah
description: Bought by the association in 1925. "The camp was used enthusiastically by all age groups in the summer, and enjoyed for brief periods even in winter. But because of the shortage of materials and transportation during the summers of World War I, it proved difficult to administer the camp, and in the following years the Camp was not sufficiently used by adults to warrant its continuation. In 1948, Camp Tinicum was reluctantly sold." (Carner)
